SINGAPORE IMPROVEMENT TRUST BUILDING STATISTICS FOR 1959


    4. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for National Development how many fiats, houses, tenements, shops and markets did the Singapore Improvement Trust start building in 1959, how many of these were completed in that year, and how many were still under construction in December, 1959.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Construction of 670 flats, 191 houses, 280 tenements, 11 shops and two markets commenced in 1959. None of these were completed during the year and therefore the same number were still under construction in December, 1959.

PUBLIC PARKS AND CULTURAL AMENITIES
(Total Cost)


    6. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for National Development what was the total cost (inclusive of (a) materials and services provided by the Public Works Department, the City Council or other Government departments, and (b) donations of drinks, materials, etc., from commercial firms and members of the public) of -

    (i) the Kallang Park project;

    (ii) the Nicoll Highway Promenade project;

    (iii) the Hong Lim Park project; and

    (iv) the orchestra and concert stage at Hong Lim Park.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: For the Kallang Park project, materials and services provided by the Public Works Department and the City Council amounted altogether to $566,265.97. Contributions from the public included 10,000 bottles of soft drinks by Bireley and Company, amounting altogether to $900; 10,000

Column: 33

bricks from Jurong Brickworks at $64 per thousand, amounting altogether to $640; 30,000 bricks from Nanyang Brickworks at five cents each, amounting altogether to $1,650. The total donation from the public was therefore $3,190. The total cost for the Kallang Park project was $569,455.97.

    The Nicoll Highway Promenade project cost $221,880 in materials and services provided by the Public Works Department and the City Council. There was no contribution from the Public.

    The Hong Lim Park together with orchestra and stage cost the Government $174,913.30. There had been again no contribution from the public towards this project.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, when the first two projects were mooted, the public was made to understand that they would be undertaken by voluntary workers and, if that is so, how could such a big amount of nearly $800,000 have been spent on them?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, I never said that the projects cost $800,000. The Kallang Park project cost $569,455 and the Nicoll Highway Promenade project cost $221,880. That was the cost which arose out of materials being used for these two projects. If we were to include the cost of voluntary labour which was put into these two projects, I would say that the ultimate cost of these two projects would have exceeded $1 million. As it is, the total sum for these two projects was only about $790,000.

SPECIALIST TRAINING FOR NURSES IN 1959


    7. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Health whether any special training for specialised jobs, such as mental nursing at Woodbridge Hospital, etc., had been conducted for nurses in 1959.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Sheng Nam Chin) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. The answer to the question is "Yes". There were training courses for psychiatric nurse training, tuberculosis nurse training, pediatrics nurse training, midwifery certificate for trained nurses, and public health nurse training.

IN CITY AREA IN 1959

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. No new scheme of "delivery after-care service" was instituted in 1959 in the City area. The existing schemes of this service were expanded during the year.

EXPANSION OF TRAFALGAR HOME IN 1959


    14. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Health whether there was any expansion of the Trafalgar Home in 1959.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was no expansion of staff, but due to better organisation and administrative facilities introduced by the P.A.P. Government, there was an expansion of work.

GOVERNMENT LOANS TO GOVERNMENT SERVANTS TO
BUILD HOUSES


    15. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance how many Government servants applied for Government loans to build houses from 1st June, 1959, to 31st May, 1960; how many of these loans were approved; and how many such houses were built and occupied by the applicants.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Low Por Tuck) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. Twenty-one Government servants applied for loans to build houses from 1st June, 1959, to 31st May, 1960. Fourteen of these applications were approved. Eight houses were built and occupied, and six are under construction.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sir, can I take it for granted that the seven applications not approved were because they were not eligible?

    Mr Low Por Tuck: Those seven were withdrawn.

ANEKA RAGAM RA'AYAT
(Total expenditure incurred)


    17. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Culture what was the total expenditure incurred up to a convenient date (including donations, etc, if any) in connection with the Aneka Ragam Ra'ayat.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. The total expenditure incurred on Aneka Ragam Ra'ayat shows from the 2nd August, 1959 to 30th June, 1960, was $18,078.29. Altogether 33 Aneka Ragam Ra'ayat concerts were held during this period. This expenditure consists of fees for artistes, refreshments, and transport for artistes, stage equipment, City Council charges and other incidentals. No donations of any kind were made to any individual or organisation in connection with the Aneka Ragam Ra'ayat.

    The Minister for Culture has asked me to repeat what he had said once in this Assembly. These cultural activities were possible only because a large number of artistes, musicians, dancers, cavatists, organisers and others gave their services, with expectation of little or no reward, to this great cause aimed at achieving cultural unity among our people.

(Construction statistics for 1959)

Only two schools, both primary, were started and substantially completed in 1959. During the whole year there was a freeze on expenditure. For the first half year it was imposed by the previous Government, while this Government imposed a freeze on taking office in order to carry out a comprehensive review of the financial resources of the State.
